job_title: Software Developer in Grand Forks, ND
pros: I was given this opportunity straight out of college with no prior professional experience. The university had several opportunities with a few different clients and internal projects when I applied. Raises were attributed to coworker interactions which I felt was fair.
cons:
There's bureaucracy and funding involved in raises. If the university did not have funding, you might not get a raise.

I loved my coworkers and have nothing bad to say about them personally. My lead was nearing retirement age and did not have an educational background in the field. I felt that I was unable to gain mentorship here. We did not employ version control like Git. We did not employ unit tests or continuous integration. We did not employ code review. Every "version" pushed to production was a nightmare. And by "pushed to production", I mean we put it on a fileshare and consumers would launch whatever was on the fileshare.

There was rarely direction. No specifications for the software that was being made. I felt like I was tasked with building software that did everything for our client. Levels of abstraction would have been great. Instead we put it all in the same interface. I was forced to reach out to scientists and ask them what they specifically wanted. They don't speak computer science and I don't speak science. It's a difficult communication barrier to overcome. I'd ask what formula calculations they wanted automated and end up with a science lesson. Perhaps I should have been better acclimated to the science to have been in this position in the first place. The bottom line is, there were no hard specifications.

There was a lot of red tape. You might be tasked with making a web application to collect benchmarks of users. In a scientific study, you'll probably run into some data that falls under HIPAA. You can mitigate this, but management won't ever review your application and determine that everything is okay (or not). It will sit in purgatory forever. Need to host your web application online? Red tape. It'll never come to fruition. Higher ups will ask you why things aren't moving along. You'll explain and go back to your supervisor. The project will stagnate.

Going back to the lack of specifications thing, I'm reminded of a project. One particular web application where I needed pictures of "healthy" foods and "unhealthy" foods. Asking the scientist running the program did not yield any information. I loaded the unhealthy section with things like beer, burgers, and sweets. I filled up the "healthy" pictures with mostly vegetables. I had asked the scientist to sort the pictures for me, but they never did. Instead, I had them coming to me and saying that beer had particular health benefits and things like carrots have lots of sugar so they may not be "healthy". This was not my research. It was hers. Yet I was left to make these decisions myself or gain information piece by piece.

You'll probably get stuck doing tech support if your less abrasive than the tech support person.

job_title: Software Developer in Grand Forks, ND
pros:
- Unionized
- no cost PPO health insurance
- 9 free credits a year
- vacation and sick leave
- federal holidays
- flexible scheduling
- great mission
- plenty of internal positions to move around in different departments/colleges for developers

The pay looks 'low' compared to jobs at private companies, you get about 30%+ in nontaxable benefits, including: free college courses, 50% tuition reduction for family members, no cost health insurance, pension, life insurance, etc.
cons:
- no bonus pay, overtime
- slow salary growth
- bureaucracy can be annoying to deal with occasionally
- benefits and pay are subject to the whims of the state legislature (although the union is pretty powerful)
- $200 parking pass every year....

job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Grand Forks, ND
pros:
They offer assistantship positions for M.S. students that include tuition waiver.
New engineering building. (Although it is mostly reserved for petroleum engineering research, which is a very transient field)
New university president is a strong leader and actually has a clue about how a good university should function and is putting effort into developing an infrastructure for impactful research and funds.
cons:
Previous engineering and University leadership must have been completely clueless and totally accepting of being a below average school.
Depending on your professor, the research opportunity might be limited, though it is getting better. This isn't an R1 school so UND is generally not that competitive for funding for impactful research. 
My advising professor treats me like an indentured servant.
They ask way too much of the TAs.
If you TA a class, that is code for you will do everything for the class and the professor (being paid to teach the class) will likely be clueless about everything regarding the class including the content.
I TA'd many lab courses for a professor who didn't even know how to change the fuse on the multimeter let alone were they acutely aware of the students or lab content.
Much of the research done is just done to publish papers. Professors are completely clueless of what is useful and what is going on in industry.
Some professors are completely dismissive to technology being developed in the private sector. Anything developed in private sector is considered as if it is trivial garbage even if it is actually more advanced and useful than what is being developed at the University.

job_title: Bus Driver in Grand Forks, ND
pros:
Get your CDL, best undergrad job on campus (as far as a mix of fun and pay are concerned), fun bus trips, awesome manager, and good people for the most part. Personal training is pretty good. Will schedule round all of your classes, very flexible scheduling. Gives you the experience and license for other higher paying CDL jobs in Grand Forks.

With a small level of dedication and about 1.5 years of seniority you can hold down all the hours you want and get to drive all the extra (off-route) bus trips. If you desire and have the availability, you can work 40+ hours a week here and make decent money. Overtime is paid time and a half for over 40 hours, and in Fall of 2015 our base rate is going up to $11.50, so $17.25 overtime.
cons: Training is unpaid-length of time to train is dependent on your learning pace. Some people get sick of having to drive the aviation van along with the bus; personally I enjoy the balance. When slots do open up for drivers (which is not that often), there is no real interview or screening process, you're just hired. This brings in some not so great employees sometimes and it's almost impossible to get rid of them once they're in. But most of the people are great to work with.

job_title: Associate Professor in Grand Forks, ND
pros: The facilities in the department are reasonably comfortable and well-maintained. The administrative staff is excellent.
cons: Working in this department as a faculty member would be attractive and appropriate for someone who is interested in an unsupportive environment that lacks collaboration, supportive management, a healthy work-life balance, and a rigorous curriculum. Overall, the department  resembles a stagnant and unchanging environment. Like many academic departments, this one is marked by faculty that do not work together in any significant manner. The curriculum is seriously outdated and is in need of extensive reform. The curriculum lacks structure and a focus on student outcomes, which were not measured or even considered much during my time there. Department chairs are not trained in personnel management, do not promote the success of other faculty, and generally act as if they don't want the job. The work-life balance is also poorly considered as the implicit, unrealistic expectation is to expect faculty to  work more and more, and with insufficient support from a curricular, academic, and administrative perspective. Also, the department gives only lip service to multi-disciplinary teaching and research, and should be considered a multi-disciplinary department.

review_title: Life as a Graduate Research Assistant
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Certain faculty members provide excellent feedback and adequate time to complete work. These often include meeting weekly or biweekly to discuss improvements to research and discussion of follow up procedures in research.
cons: One major downside is that professors are people too. They have other obligations and they have a notorious tendency to slinky through the semester. Being hypervigilant and useful in the first few weeks of the semester. Then taking a back seat role with little communication or aid. Then when they feel the semester is nearing a close they present a significant amount of work. This effect has been observed with multiple of my colleagues and across multiple graduate departments.

review_title: Good place to gain experience, hard to turn into career.
job_title: Flight Instructor in Grand Forks, ND
pros: The culture is geared towards progress. Communication is very easy between every employee and management. Plenty of work when you want it, and plenty of time off when you don't. Pay is comparable, but could be better. Excellent facilities, personnel and aircraft. One of the best places to be a flight instructor or mechanic. Team effort around every corner with management willing to listen to ideas to improve.
cons: Due to significant size growth, there are still some growing pains dealing with how to ensure everyone gains the skills they need on time. Pay is ok, but hard to build a family or gain a safety net. Benefits are basic. Politics play a significant role in a number of career progressions. Being in an academic field, most employees are hired from the inside, and are colleagues from classes and clubs. Location can have hostile weather in the winter and heat of summer.

job_title: Laboratory Technician in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Great programs for minorities and are really trying to make it a university that people want to be at....plus one word HOCKEY!
cons: Grand Forks is cold! And all the work being done by the university is not helping the attitude of the community.  Its not the greatest place to live and parking at UND is horrible and expensive.  I've never had to pay so much for a parking pass.  Plus it seems the rule are ambiquous and they will ticket you in a heart beat.  Also there is not a lot of female instructors. Or minority ones.

job_title: Certified Flight Instructor in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Lots of Flight time for those looking to build hours. This far outweighs the perceived lower level of compensation. Oh and the oldest aircraft in the fleet is from 2008 and they are getting brand new 2017 aircraft with the latest avionics.
cons: Pay can seem to be lower. However you get a lot more hours than at other flight schools and you get exposed to a lot more students, styles of learning, and weather. Oh by the way, it is North Dakota. It is COLD in the winter.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Huntsville, AL
pros: Nice pay and great benefits for graduate students.
cons: The Communication Department itself needs lots of work with staff, organization, communication, and getting its program working properly to best benefit the students that it serves. If you go in to teach public speaking, be expected to conform to an exact syllabus and teach exact the same way all other 15 instructors are teaching. You get no wiggle room to be creative, innovative, or teach the way you believe the class should be taught. There is very strong emphasis on every instructor teaching the exact same way so that every student in all 30 different sections have the exact same experience.

review_title: My experience was very good with my professors in the Engineering Department.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Grand Forks, ND
pros: When I worked here I graded papers and tests and did research for the University.  I learned a lot during my research and I was able to do almost anything I wanted for my research which was great.
cons: My job at the University has very few cons.  However,  there were multiple times while attending UND I was forgotten for scholarships that I had won.  I lost over 15,000 dollars worth of scholarships because my name was missed or not added to a list.

review_title: UND has its upside, but is on a downslide
job_title: Associate Professor in Grand Forks, ND
pros: I am (tenure track) faculty, and at UND faculty usually have a say in their annual goals and job description.  There is a fair amount of flexibility in this job.  It is a great place to be if you are one of the "desired" faculty -- aviation, engineering, business, medicine, law, or biology.  If you are not in one of these fields, then be prepared to be treated as a pointless burden to society.  Still, if you are on a tenure track you can get decent pay, some job security, and some great colleagues (i.e. instructors/professors and staff).  I appreciate the benefits, such as health insurance and TIAA/CREF retirement, with some of the retirement funds put in by my employer.  Also, there is a tuition break if you or an immediate family member takes classes here.  I also appreciate the incremental raises and opportunities for me to do community service.
cons: The money is tight and enrollments are down.  Even before that started, the administration started a downslide about three or four years ago and seems to have no united vision for the university.  The physical climate is harsh, sure, but the main problem is that campus climate is poor (I wrote this late in 2016).  The demands on my time & peace of mind are such that the job is negatively impacting my health, which is not a good sign.

job_title: Accounting Technician in Grand Forks, ND
pros:
Very flexible with my schedule, I usually came in after everyone else had gone home to work on the books.

Friendly coworkers

Nice boss

Free gym membership, discounts on tuition and other things at the University.
cons:
Not a lot of people working when I did

Not many people to a department, my boss and I were the whole accounting department so I felt like I was always pestering her because she was the only person to ask when I had questions.

Parking can be bad when the hockey games are happening at the University

review_title: A great place to start a career
job_title: Programmer I in London, England
pros: The people were fantastic, and the company was very accommodating to personal schedules and technology preferences.
cons: High turnover rate and low pay, though I hear the latter has now been remedied to some degree.

job_title: Librarian in London, England
pros: Not too big, not too small. Professors seem to genuinely care about students. Healthcare is free to staff and faculty.
cons: Winter. More money is put into marketing to new students than retaining staff and faculty. UND is not nearly as great as administration thinks it is.  Thanks to local economy every department had to cut 10% of their budget and forfeit cost of living increases for 2 years.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Grand Forks, ND
pros: A very social community of coworkers and gets you a really good knowledge of campus resources that most of us didn't bother to learn about as freshman. Also develops a lot of skills you can apply later in life.
cons: Is a very dynamic environment that can be confusing at times and exhausting.

job_title: Certified Flight Instructor in Stockbridge, England
pros: UND knows what they're up to, airplanes are best maintained GA airplanes in the world, safety is extremely high on the priority list, management generally will back CFIs as long as you do your job to the best of your ability and don't do anything too stupid.
cons: Pay isn't great, don't get paid much during the winter due to awful weather, students are hit or miss, but that's not the school's fault, nature of flight instructing.

review_title: Great University to be apart of!
job_title: in Minnetonka, MN
pros: Everyone that works at UND is very friendly and helpful. There is plenty of things to get involved in and lots of opportunity for growth if you are willing to live in Grand Forks.
cons: There is a lot of changes happening at the University right now with budget cuts and a search for a new president and VP cabinet underway. This could mean lots of changes at all levels of the university.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Small College town, low cost of living, pay is good, flexible in timing, great work ethic
cons: Less opportunities to climb the ladder, management is bureaucratic

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Grand Forks, ND
pros: The professor I teach for is an extraordinary person professionally and personally.  He always makes sure we are prepared and understand lectures and labs before we encounter the students.  He is not in control of compensation, but he is very generous with doughnuts for our weekly meetings and beer and dinner at the end of the semester!
cons: Budget cuts have made it difficult to update equipment, proper benefits/compensation.

review_title: utter chaos in a educational institution
job_title: Support Tech in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Learn more about laptop repairs, Supervisor is great, Satisfaction in problem solving with a viral laptop or replacing a motherboard
cons: Upper Management is not competent enough to run a tech department (very very lazy), based off of same job with another University.

job_title: Technical Support for Athletics Department in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Spare time can be spent working on classwork/studying, and the crew is really nice. Very flexible scheduling. Onboarding process is very helpful.
cons: There can be lots of time spent just... waiting... on updates or installations. Try surrounding yourself with something to do so when you're just waiting you can keep yourself occupied.

job_title: in Grand Forks, ND
pros: With a friendly boss, friendly co-workers and a good payment (as an on-campus institutional job), anyone will have a good time working here
cons: The only con I can think of is having a computer which is not that fast. Sometimes the computer is the only thing which makes the work take a long time

review_title: It was fun to work at UND
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Grand Forks, ND
pros:
TA job at UND is easy, you only need to give 10-15hr per week and you will get full time TA. There is less number of student and it will be easy to do grading kinds of stuff. Professors are really kind and helpful.
Nice place to stay (less people, less crowd).
cons: Rating of University if not that good.

review_title: Worst experience ever--Earth System Science and Policy Department !!!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Grand Forks, ND
pros: I was working for Earth System Science and Policy Department. The pros I found was that the workplace had small working group, good attitude co-workers.
cons: Professors of the Earth System Science and Policy Department are the real craps. They take personal biases with their fellow co-workers & students and their inflated ego is very hard to deal with. Very negative attitude personnel I ever confronted in my entire life.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Great autonomy from my senior management which lead to pursuit of my own research projects and interests. Varied and challenging work for projects that I greatly enjoyed.
cons: As you may expect from a large University the bureaucracy can be daunting.  Easy to get lost in such a large organization where people overseeing your paper work may never see you in person.

job_title: Assistant Director of Athletic Media Relations in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Passion, pride, honor, commitment to excellence. Fun work environment, plenty of perks and an awesome benefits package.
cons: Salary and cold. Lots of cold. Yes it's cold. And you can't park anywhere. And there's no chipotle in town.

job_title: Brand Journalist in Grand Forks, ND
pros: It was fun and a fast-paced environment. It allowed me to expand my video editing skills.
cons: It was a small team and the pay wasn't that great. I was looking for a longer term career.

job_title: in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Good opportunities to interact w/ students. Very helpful staff and competent senior management
cons: Little organization/groups don't get the limelight.  Would like to see a better recognition of all groups on campus.

job_title: in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Great place to work, fun, and enjoyable.
cons: You have to pay for parking, sometimes there are limited spots.  Depending on the position you may need to find work for the summer months.

job_title: Network Administrator in Grand Forks, ND
pros: good benefits for families. nice people and nice place to work. in general people are friendly and nice..
cons: salaries are not good. compare to other universities, und is one of the worst for salary.

review_title: UND is a wonderful place to work as a pilot.
job_title: Flight Instructor in Grand Forks, ND
pros: UND takes care of you. The benefits are excellent. Pay is great compared to other flight instructor jobs in the country.
cons: The weather is not ideal in North Dakota. Winter is colder than most places in the country and can last 6 months.

review_title: So far so good, have no major issues.  Some coworkers are mehh, some are awesome.   Just depends.
job_title: Aircraft Refueler in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Works great around a students schedule.
cons:
Some late nights
Pay
Some of management changing things on a daily basis.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Great university to learn to teach without a huge research load right away. Salaries are on the rise compared to competition for master's level universities
cons: Cost of living, especially housing, is on the rise. The weather is horrible, and sometimes the relationship between the university and locals is frayed.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Good benefits (medical and classes).  (Mostly) Friendly employees.
cons: Stifled vertical career movement.  Pay is significantly lower than equivalent jobs in industry. Many administrative employees seem to have a "work for the weekend" mentality.  Really depends on the department though, but I don't get a drive for success.

review_title: nice and great place to work. nice and great place to work. nice and great place to work.
job_title: Resident Manager in Grand Forks, ND
pros: great work atmosphere nice and great place to work. nice and great place to work.
cons: cold weather in the winter, have to walk out often which is terrible

job_title: in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Friendly environment, good pay, Almost zero amount of stress
cons: Unprofessional, lack of motivation and team work, a lot of work behind the curtain. There is an intention to give opportunities to those who know the right people and are recommended. Rather than what kind of skills and qualities they posses.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great opportunity to work closely with advisors and other faculty.  They were supportive and experts in their fields.
cons: Distance to hometown in Minnesota.  Difficult travel in the winter.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: Great work life balance, Positive environment, Flexible schedule as long as you get work done, organized, smaller company
cons: Working at UND was great the worst part was braving the cold to get to work. I can not complain about much!

job_title: Assistant in Boston, MA
pros:
Conveniently on campus location, was able to walk to work almost the entire time i worked there
easy to punch in and out
cons:
Pay was right near minimum wage, which in North Dakota is only 7.25
Some of the people in the building can be incredibly rude

review_title: Great Place to Work as a Grad Student
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Crystal, MN
pros: I was a graduate assistant at UND and really enjoyed my experience there.  I found the work environment to have an appropriate level of both challenge and support.
cons: No cons really - I had a great experience.

job_title: Graduate Service Assistant in Grand Forks, ND
pros: At 15-20 hours a week, my pro-rated stipend was higher than my supervisor's salary. I would hit my work quota, then work on school work.
cons: I have no complaints about working there.

review_title: Generally good place to work until your department gets gutted
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Grand Forks, ND
pros:
Flexible working around classwork
Laid back atmosphere
Generally good mid-level management
cons: Upper management makes the worst financial decisions

job_title: Flight Instructor in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Guaranteed hours, very organized part 141 school, separate records department that keeps track of all student records.
cons: No work hour security - although pay is usually sufficient, during periods of extended bad weather, you get no pay as you are hourly.

job_title: Professor in Grand Forks, ND
pros: A medium quality education with exception of aviation and rural medicine (excellent).
cons: The state cut budgets to the  point of faculty loosing positions and depleting departments of full potential of it's intended goals: education

review_title: Worst in the US for graduate student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Grand Forks, ND
pros:
-Friendly work environment.
- Good facilities to gain experience
cons:
-Poor compensation for graduate assistants at the department of Petroleum Engineering.
Don't expect any stipend in your first semester.
After your first semester you are given 14,400 per yr as stipend ($1200/mo) before tax. In addition you pay your own fees and health insurance. This is the worst in the US! Be prepared.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Grand Forks, ND
pros: great place to work while earning a degree. My graduate assistantship paid $700 a month for 7-10hours of work a week. I did not have to pay tuition, only student fees.
cons: location, very cold. you do not choose your assistantship, they place you.

job_title: University of North Dakota, Computer Lab Supervisor in Grand Forks, ND
pros:
Relaxing job
Great hours
Make sure the labs are stocked
Pass on knowledge to up and coming students
Get some homework done
cons:
Late shifts during the week and long shifts on rotating weekends.
Not many workers so it was hard to get days off.

job_title: Ph D Candidate in Grand Forks, ND
pros: The university gives an opportunity for international students to pursue the higher degree. The work here I'm doing in Dr. Du'd lab is pretty novel and inspiring.
cons: Don't have many options to make connections and collaborations with other researchers.

review_title: Great university, proud of have worked there
job_title: Enrollment Services in Grand Forks, ND
pros: High quality institution, supportive environment, opportunities for learning and advancement, great benefits.
cons: Hard work not always financially rewarded; under-performers are rarely let go and often receive similar pay as top performers.

job_title: Building Manager in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Worked with my school schedule as a student. Solid working hours and decent pay for the area.
cons: Had to show up despite the weather but the people were usually understanding

review_title: Graduate Teaching/Research Assistant at the University of North Dakota
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Lots of freedom to work from home, could set own hours, compensation seemed more than fair.
cons: Most job tasks were not overly exciting or thought provoking.

review_title: Good place to work, good benefits, stable job.
